results.title: World bank
results.creator_credit: James Lipscomb and United States Information Agency

An official of the bank makes a trip to a country to make certain that the request for a $21 million loan to build a highway will indeed help to develop the area and really benefit the people of the country.

results.title: World at your feet
results.creator_credit: Larry Gosnell, Michael Spencer and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Man’s inevitable and invaluable associate, the soil, is shown in a new light, a veritable thriving community in miniature, populated by living things of the animal, plant and insect worlds, some draining the soil of its usefulness, others contributing to its productivity. How this soil world maintains a harmonious balance is shown in highly magnified sequences employing time-lapse photography and photomicrography. The film deals extensively with soil substance, analysing different types of soil structure and their resistance to varying natural conditions. Suggestions are made as to how man can make his own contributions to the good of the earth.

results.title: World around us: chain of life
results.brief_description: Illustrates nature’s methods of making food chains which tie together all the living creature in a community, making one dependent on the others for its existence. The film includes close-ups of tadpoles eating algae, crayfish catching and eating tadpoles, links in the food chain through green bass, fish eggs, a Polythemus moth is hatched from its cocoon and a spider builds its web - to trap some other creatures and complete the “chain of life”.

results.title: Working women of the world [Widescreen] = Ouvieres du monde
results.creator_credit: Marie-France Collard, ARTE Belgique, CRRV Nord Pas-de-Calais, Latitudes Productions, Moviemento Productions, Radio Television Belge Francophone (RTBF) and W I P Wallonie Image Productions
results.brief_description: An amazing documentary filmed in Belgium, France, Turkey, Indonesia and the Philippines, about Levi Strauss Europe and their intentions in 1998 to restructure its European activities by closing three factories in Belgium and one in France creating a loss of 1400 jobs. The arguments given for these closures were over-production problems, excessive social security contributions and a decreasing market. However as the film progresses it is quite clear that Levi Strauss Europe’s aim is to relocate to the developing countries of the world such as Indonesia, Turkey and the Philippines where workers’ rights are almost non-existent with deplorable and repressive working regimes, low wages, child labor, and union involvement either not encouraged or not allowed, so that the multinational company can cut costs, increase productivity and increase profits. Through Rosa (an employee in one of the Belgium Levi factories), Maria Therese (an employee and union representative in the Levi factory in Yser La Basse in France) and Yanti (an employee in an Indonesian factory) allowing themselves to be filmed and interviewed, we learn of the conditions and the fears which plague these women daily, their stresses and in Yanti’s case, the excessively long hours of work - upto 80 hours a week - of Rosa’s fortitude and of Maria Therese’s attempts through negotiations with government and management to prevent the closures/relocations and subsequent redundancies. An interesting expose of multinationals and globalisation, large scale redundancies and international restructurings. In French and other languages with English subtitles.

results.title: Working with display screen equipment
results.brief_description: A program on health and safety issues for people working with display screen equipment. It examines basic ergonomics, layout of the workplace, job design, hazards that exist and ways to reduce or control the problem. The program emphasises the need to take individual variations in physical characteristics into account when setting up display screen equipment workstations and operating procedures.
